Sus voces, aunque ocultas por el ruido del huracán, eran claras y determinadas. "¡Libertad para todos los prisioneros de la República!", exclamaban en un unísono, dejando claro que su causa era más que una simple demanda de piedad; era una declaración de guerra contra las prácticas opresivas del régimen. Entre las olas, algunos prisioneros, con expresiones de esperanza y resignación combinadas, intentaban alcanzar el borde del barco, extendiendo sus manos hacia los marineros que, por su parte, parecían confundidos y divididos. Algunos intentaban negarse a la posibilidad de liberar a estos individuos, temiendo las consecuencias, mientras que otros, impulsados por una mezcla de empatía y justicia, consideraban que era su deber actuar de acuerdo con la ley marítima internacional, que prohíbe la tortura y garantiza los derechos humanos. En el centro del caos, un capitán, vestido con el uniforme más limpio, intentaba mantener el orden, pero sus ordenes eran inútiles ante la furia del mar y la determinación de los prisioneros. "¡No se pueden dejar morir!", gritaba una voz desde el interior del barco, mientras el capitán, con una voz que intentaba ser firme pero que se desvanecía ante el ruido, ordenaba a sus hombres que mantuvieran la distancia. La escena era una mezcla de drama, heroísmo y un claro recordatorio de los conflictos internos que a menudo surgen en tiempos de crisis, donde las leyes y la ética se enfrentan en un dilema moral.

Similarly, during two or three hours of drawl, and the winnowing of many bushels of words, Madame Defarge’s frequent interruptions, with her sharp, shrill voice, and her vehement gesticulations, kept the crowd in a state of excited attention. She would stop a speaker in full flow, pointing with her knitting-needles toward the prison, and then, with a fierce energy that made her lean forward as she spoke, she would pour forth her own narrative. Her stories were vivid, filled with passion and a relentless focus on the theme of revenge. She spoke of the wrongs done to her sister, to her brother, to her father, and to herself, all by the hands of the aristocracy and the privileged few. She painted a picture of a society rife with injustice, where the common people suffered under the yoke of the rich and powerful, and where the guillotine was the only true equalizer. Her words stirred the hearts of the listeners, many of whom had their own grievances and tales of oppression. As the sun began to set, casting long shadows over the city, the crowd around Madame Defarge grew denser, her influence stronger, her resolve firmer. The clatter of her knitting needles, each click echoing her silent vow of retribution, became a rhythmic undercurrent to her impassioned speeches. The air was thick with anticipation, the murmurs of agreement, and the occasional dissenting voice drowned out by the clamor of the mob. It was clear that Madame Defarge was not merely knitting; she was weaving a tapestry of vengeance, each stitch a promise of the justice she intended to mete out. Her satisfaction, once a private emotion, had become a public spectacle, a spectacle that would soon have far-reaching consequences for all within the walls of the prison and beyond.
